title: Naming Words – The First Declension Begins
goals: Teach that Latin nouns change endings to show jobs in a sentence
Learn the -a (subject) and -am (object) forms with rosa
Connect the idea of order in grammar to God's order in creation

steps.speak: Salve iterum! Let’s greet one another: Salve, vale, pax, Deus, rosa!
Faith phrase: Pax vobiscum – Peace be with you. Say it slowly, then together with open hands.
Yesterday we learned that a noun names something. Today we’ll see how its ending changes. In Latin, endings tell the noun’s job!
Here’s our model noun: rosa – rose. Say it: rosa.
When the rose does the action, we say 'rosa'. When something happens to the rose, we say 'rosam'.
Chant with me: rosa (subject), rosam (object). Point to yourself for rosa, point outward for rosam!
Let’s use them: Rosa floret – The rose blooms. Video rosam – I see the rose.
Mini-quiz! I say a Latin word, you tell me if it’s the doer or the receiver. Ready? Rosa… Rosam…
Derivative time: rosa gives us rose and rosary; pax gives us pacify; Deus gives us deity.
Beautiful work! God made order in language—endings show meaning. Tomorrow we’ll add more words and practice again. Vale!
